blocks.text: attached, the $a$ and $b$ being replaced by the English forms $f$ and $d$ respectively, so that the area between the curve and the axis of $x$ is the area that is not defined by the given formula.
Hence $f(x)$ is spoken of as an indefinite integral.

The $f$ that is given by the area in this case will depend on the values given to $x$. Suppose that when $x = AB$, $x = a$, and when $x = CD$, $x = b$; then the range of $x$ is from $a$ to $b$ and the area $ABC$ found is a function of these limits.

blocks.description: This represents the integral of the function $f(x)$ from the lower limit $a$ to the upper limit $b.

blocks.text: It is usually written as $F(x)$, that is, the quantity derived from it.
Now we admit that $ABC$ is a finite area between one value only, and thus $\int_a^b f(x)$ is termed a definite integral.
The most convenient method for evaluating this quantity is that treated in Part I, Chap. VII; that is, to consider it being expressed in terms of its integrand.

Next this will be illustrated by the case of the integral of a vertical line, as $BM$. A pole $P$ now stands to the left of that line; this, therefore, forms part of the polar diagram; being a round motion about the vertical axis.
